medical_history.chief_complaint: Generalized calcific nodules, progressive contractures, and muscle weakness.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began at six years of age with trouble bending knees, leading to progressive contractures and proximal muscle weakness predominantly affecting the elbows and knees. At seven, the first calcific nodule appeared on his right upper arm after a fall, followed by multiple nodules on the trunk and extremities without trauma. Skin eruptions developed, exposing white chalky material. Overall, the symptoms have progressed since onset.
medical_history.family_history: No family history of Progressive osseous heteroplasia, poikiloderma, or pulmonary fibrosis; fraternal sister is unaffected.
